New-York Historical Society
Ferdinand Roth slides of New York City
Roth, Ferdinand, 1906-1971.
PR 457
3 folder(s) in 1 box (44 color slides).
1951, 1952, [1958] Color slides capturing balloons and floats in the 1951 and 1952 Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parades, and the lighted neon signs of Times Square around 1958. This collection may be stored offsite. To arrange an appointment to view it, please see www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
Access Restrictions
This collection may be stored offsite. To arrange an appointment to view it, please see www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of Margaret Ann Roth (daughter of the photographer), 2021.
Arrangement
The collection is housed in three folders in one box.
Biographical note
Ferdinand Roth (1906-1971) began his civil service career in 1941 as a real estate analyst with the New York City Bureau of Real Estate of the Board of Estimate. He served as Commissioner of Real Estate in 1960-1962, and later as president of Wm. C. Walker Sons, a real estate management concern, from 1966 until his death.
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as the "Ferdinand Roth Slides of New York City, PR-457, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society."
Processing Information
Archivist Joseph Ditta processed this collection in April 2023.
Scope and Contents
Roth's slides of Macy's 1951 Thanksgiving Day Parade show the balloons "Toy Soldier," "Rainbow Trout," "Mighty Mouse" (debuted 1951), "Dachshund," and "Hobo Clown." His slides of the 1952 parade show the balloons "Crocodile," "Mighty Mouse," "The Spaceman" (debuted 1952), "Rainbow Trout," and "Teddy Bear," as well as the floats "American Eagle," "Mississippi River Showboat," "Chiquita Banana's Tropical Garden" (sole appearance), "Noah's Ark," "Sonny the Bunny," "The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T" (sole appearance; advertisement for an upcoming musical film), "The Spaceship" (debuted 1952), "Calliope Circus," and "Santa's Sleigh." Roth's night views of the neon lights of Times Square were likely taken in 1958, based on the presence of advertisements for "A Night to Remember" and "The Big Country," two films which premiered that year. Other signs advertise "Pepsi Cola," "TWA," and "Time-Life," and two views show store windows displaying Halloween candy and popular record albums.
